elements.content: Peptides are attractive ligands for the design of metal organic frameworks, with the potential to confer chirality and biological activity on these materials. However, very few such materials have been reported. Here we describe the X-ray structures of four extended molecular framework compounds formed by the complexation of di- and tripeptides with cadmium ions. The tripeptide complex of cadmium with glycine, Cd(Gly3)2·H2O, forms a two-dimensional complex in which the carboxylate group of the peptide bridges between Cd ions. In contrast, the tripeptide complex of cadmium with alanine, Cd(l-Ala3)2, forms a one-dimensional extended molecular chain comprised of an infinite series of rings linked together through the Cd ions. The dipeptide complexes Cd(l-Ala2)2 and Cd(l-Ala,l-Thr)2·4H2O form covalently linked two-dimensional square lattices. Hydrogen bonding between peptide amide groups and hydrophobic interactions between side chains are seen to play important roles in defining these extended structures. Most interestingly, substitution of the more hydrophilic threonine side chain in place of alanine introduces a layer of water molecules into the crystal lattice. These results suggest that it may be possible to engineer the properties of these extended networks through judicious choice of amino acid side chains.

elements.content: Chiral crystalline materials comprising complexes of cadmium ions and short peptides have been synthesized that form extended one- and two-dimensional networks. The peptides coordinate cadmium through the N-terminal amino group and the C-terminal carboxyl group to propagate the network. Hydrogen bonding between peptide amide groups and hydrophobic interactions between side chains are seen to play important roles in defining these structures.

elements.content: The design of new molecular architectures based on the coordination of metal ions with a variety of bridging organic ligands, to produce either discrete molecular complexes or extended molecular solids (metal−organic frameworks, MOFs), has been an area of explosive growth in recent years. As well as the intrinsic intellectual interest associated with the design and characterization of new compounds, such materials may have important applications. In particular, much interest has focused on porous materials for applications such as gas storage, separations, and catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of new molecular architectures based on the coordination of metal ions with a variety of bridging organic ligands, to produce either discrete molecular complexes or extended molecular solids (metal-organic frameworks, MOFs), has been an area of explosive growth in recent years. As well as the intrinsic intellectual interest associated with the design and characterization of new compounds, such materials may have important applications. In particular, much interest has focused on porous materials for applications such as gas storage, separations, and catalysis.

elements.content: There has also been considerable interest in expanding the functional repertoire of MOFs by incorporating more complex organic ligands into MOF assemblies. Using multidentate metal-coordinating ligands, instead of simple organic ligands, it has been possible to introduce new magnetic, optical, and electronic properties into MOFs. Furthermore, by using ligands that retain an open coordination site at the metal center, it has been possible to design catalytic properties into these materials. However, nonporous materials may exhibit interesting magnetic, optical, and electronic properties and may have valuable pharmacological properties.
elements.clean_text: There has also been considerable interest in expanding the functional repertoire of MOFs by incorporating more complex organic ligands into MOF assemblies. Using multidentate metal-coordinating ligands, instead of simple organic ligands, it has been possible to introduce new magnetic, optical, and electronic properties into MOFs. Furthermore, by using ligands that retain an open coordination site at the metal center, it has been possible to design catalytic properties into these materials. However, nonporous materials may exhibit interesting magnetic, optical, and electronic properties and may have valuable pharmacological properties.

elements.content: In this paper we describe the structures of one- and two-dimensional MOFs in which the ligands are short peptides. Peptides are attractive ligands for designing MOFs, as they are both easy to synthesize and extremely versatile. The peptide sequence can be varied in a predictable and modular fashion, allowing a high degree of structural and functional diversity to be incorporated into the material. Peptides readily bind metals through their amino- and carboxyl-termini and through various side chains. Lastly, hydrogen bonding between backbone amide groups provides the potential for “secondary” structure forming interactions between peptides.
elements.clean_text: In this paper we describe the structures of one- and two-dimensional MOFs in which the ligands are short peptides. Peptides are attractive ligands for designing MOFs, as they are both easy to synthesize and extremely versatile. The peptide sequence can be varied in a predictable and modular fashion, allowing a high degree of structural and functional diversity to be incorporated into the material. Peptides readily bind metals through their amino- and carboxyl-termini and through various side chains. Lastly, hydrogen bonding between backbone amide groups provides the potential for "secondary" structure forming interactions between peptides.

elements.content: Metal−peptide frameworks have the potential to be a large and novel class of compounds with potential pharmacological applications. However, only a few scattered examples are reported that are limited to dipeptide linkers. Here we describe a series of extended peptide−metal framework structures based on dipeptides and tripeptides. Their structures may be rationalized in much the same way as protein structures: by invoking the need to satisfy hydrogen bonding interactions between backbone amide groups and the formation of hydrophobic cores by packing together hydrophobic amino acid side chains. These structures also suggest some basic design “rules” for constructing 1-D and 2-D frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Metal-peptide frameworks have the potential to be a large and novel class of compounds with potential pharmacological applications. However, only a few scattered examples are reported that are limited to dipeptide linkers. Here we describe a series of extended peptide-metal framework structures based on dipeptides and tripeptides. Their structures may be rationalized in much the same way as protein structures: by invoking the need to satisfy hydrogen bonding interactions between backbone amide groups and the formation of hydrophobic cores by packing together hydrophobic amino acid side chains. These structures also suggest some basic design "rules" for constructing 1-D and 2-D frameworks.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Peptides either were purchased from Sigma Chemical Co. or were synthesized by standard liquid phase peptide coupling and deprotection methods using boc-protected monomers. All other reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification.

elements.content:
All complexes were crystallized by the base diffusion method. The crystallization trials were conducted at room temperature, which varied between 20 and 25 °C.

Synthesis of Cd(Gly<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of CdAc2 (14 mg, 0.05 mmol) and Gly3 tripeptide (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) in 2.0 mL of DMF, water, and ethanol (1:1:1.5) was prepared. The solution was sonicated for 5 min with gentle shaking at 150 w using a Fisher Scientific FS60 ultrasonic bath and placed in a 5 mL glass vial, which was in turn was placed in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. One milliliter of 2% triethylamine in ethanol solution was added to the 20 mL vial and sealed with a cap. After about 3 months, colorless needles had grown; these were separated, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (59% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm−1): 3453, 3293, 3100, 2938, 2816, 1675, 1649, 1577, 1423, 1381, 1290, 1258, 1061, 1027, 1015, 715, 596, 477.

elements.content: Crystals of complexes 1−4 were mounted on a standard Bruker SMART 1K CCD-based X-ray diffractometer equipped with a LT-2 low-temperature device and a normal focus Mo-target X-ray tube (λ = 0.71073 Å) operated at 2000 W power (50 kV, 40 mA). The final cell constants (Table ) were based on the xyz centroids of reflections above 10σ(I). Analysis of the data showed negligible decay during data collection; the data were processed with SADABS and corrected for absorption. The structures were solved and refined with the Bruker SHELXTL (version 6.12) software package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms placed in idealized or refined positions. Figures of the molecular structures were produced using the Mercury program. Further crystal structure and refinement data for all of the complexes are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Crystals of complexes 1-4 were mounted on a standard Bruker SMART 1K CCD-based X-ray diffractometer equipped with a LT-2 low-temperature device and a normal focus Mo-target X-ray tube (λ = 0.71073 Å) operated at 2000 W power (50 kV, 40 mA). The final cell constants (Table ) were based on the xyz centroids of reflections above 10σ(I). Analysis of the data showed negligible decay during data collection; the data were processed with SADABS and corrected for absorption. The structures were solved and refined with the Bruker SHELXTL (version 6.12) software package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms placed in idealized or refined positions. Figures of the molecular structures were produced using the Mercury program. Further crystal structure and refinement data for all of the complexes are summarized in Table .

Our starting point in this project was the prototypical metal−peptide framework of diglycine coordinated by cadmium, Cd(Gly2)2·H2O, which was previously shown by Takayama et al. to form a 2-D network comprising carboxylate-bridged cadmium ions in one dimension and N-to-C-terminal peptide-linked cadmium ions in the second dimension (Figure ). We therefore decided to examine how the peptide may influence the type of network formed by either extending the length of the peptide linker or changing the side chains of the peptide. Initially, we took a conservative approach to modifying the peptide linker, focusing on triglycine, dialanine, and trialanine as linkers. These peptides were screened for their ability to form crystals in complex with various divalent metal ions including Cd, Zn, Cu, Mn, Cr, Co, Fe, Mg, and Pb. However, only cadmium produced high quality diffracting crystals under the conditions employed in the screen. (The Gly3 peptide also gave crystals with zinc, but these were of poor quality and not characterized further.) The crystallographic data for each of the complexes described below are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Results

Our starting point in this project was the prototypical metal-peptide framework of diglycine coordinated by cadmium, Cd(Gly2)2⋅H2O, which was previously shown by Takayama et al. to form a 2-D network comprising carboxylate-bridged cadmium ions in one dimension and N-to-C-terminal peptide-linked cadmium ions in the second dimension (Figure ). We therefore decided to examine how the peptide may influence the type of network formed by either extending the length of the peptide linker or changing the side chains of the peptide. Initially, we took a conservative approach to modifying the peptide linker, focusing on triglycine, dialanine, and trialanine as linkers. These peptides were screened for their ability to form crystals in complex with various divalent metal ions including Cd, Zn, Cu, Mn, Cr, Co, Fe, Mg, and Pb. However, only cadmium produced high quality diffracting crystals under the conditions employed in the screen. (The Gly3 peptide also gave crystals with zinc, but these were of poor quality and not characterized further.) The crystallographic data for each of the complexes described below are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table .

elements.content: Network formed by the prototypical metal−peptide framework complex Cd(Gly2)2·H2O: (A) When viewed along the crystallographic b axis, the extended network formed by the bridging diglycine linkers is clearly illustrated. Note: In this view, the Cd ions are eclipsed so that it appears that the carboxylate groups form bidentate ligands to cadmium, but this is not the case. As shown in part B, when viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the 8-membered rings formed by Cd-bridging carboxylate groups are clearly displayed.
elements.clean_text: 1  Network formed by the prototypical metal-peptide framework complex Cd(Gly2)2⋅H2O: (A) When viewed along the crystallographic b axis, the extended network formed by the bridging diglycine linkers is clearly illustrated. Note: In this view, the Cd ions are eclipsed so that it appears that the carboxylate groups form bidentate ligands to cadmium, but this is not the case. As shown in part B, when viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the 8-membered rings formed by Cd-bridging carboxylate groups are clearly displayed.

elements.content: To determine the effects of extending the peptide linker on structure and dimensionality, we crystallized the cadmium triglycine complex, Cd(Gly3)2·H2O. The complex crystallized as monoclinic crystals belonging to the space group C2/c. The structure, illustrated in Figure , is exactly analogous to that of the dipeptide complex. Each Cd ion is octahedrally ligated by six peptides: the N-termini of two peptides supply two apical nitrogen ligands, and one oxygen from each of four C-terminal carboxylates supply four equatorial ligands. Each carboxylate group bridges two Cd ions to form chains of eight-membered rings that extend the molecular framework in one dimension. The second dimension of the framework is formed by the peptide backbone: the triglycine peptides adopt an extended conformation, with two peptides running antiparallel to each other to form a ring that is closed by ligation to two cadmium ions. Hydrogen bonding plays an important role in the structure, with all four potential peptide backbone hydrogen bonds being satisfied. Each peptide forms two hydrogen bonds with its partner across the covalently closed ring. Two more hydrogen bonds are formed with peptides in adjacent layers that serve to extend the crystal in the third dimension.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Cd(Gly3)2⋅H2O (1)

To determine the effects of extending the peptide linker on structure and dimensionality, we crystallized the cadmium triglycine complex, Cd(Gly3)2⋅H2O. The complex crystallized as monoclinic crystals belonging to the space group C2/c. The structure, illustrated in Figure , is exactly analogous to that of the dipeptide complex. Each Cd ion is octahedrally ligated by six peptides: the N-termini of two peptides supply two apical nitrogen ligands, and one oxygen from each of four C-terminal carboxylates supply four equatorial ligands. Each carboxylate group bridges two Cd ions to form chains of eight-membered rings that extend the molecular framework in one dimension. The second dimension of the framework is formed by the peptide backbone: the triglycine peptides adopt an extended conformation, with two peptides running antiparallel to each other to form a ring that is closed by ligation to two cadmium ions. Hydrogen bonding plays an important role in the structure, with all four potential peptide backbone hydrogen bonds being satisfied. Each peptide forms two hydrogen bonds with its partner across the covalently closed ring. Two more hydrogen bonds are formed with peptides in adjacent layers that serve to extend the crystal in the third dimension.

We next sought to examine how the introduction of chirality by addition of the simple methyl group of alanine would modulate the structure of the metal−peptide framework. We therefore crystallized the complex of trialanine with cadmium and determined its structure. The complex crystallized as monoclinic crystals belonging to the chiral space group C2. Cd(Ala3)2 (2) forms a one-dimensional extended molecular chain comprised of an infinite series of rings linked together through the Cd ions (Figure ). In this case, each Cd is octahedrally coordinated by four trialanine peptides, as steric hindrance from the methyl side chains prevents the carboxylate groups from bridging between Cd ions (cf. the triglycine complex). Carboxylate groups from two peptides coordinate each Cd in a monodentate fashion; the N-termini of the other two peptides supply two nitrogen ligands, and the N-terminal amide carbonyl oxygens provide the final two ligands to the metal.

elements.content: (A) Structure of Cd(Ala3)2 (2). (B) Packing of two methyl groups within the center of each ring to form a hydrophobic core. (C) View along the crystallographic b axis illustrating the 1-D chain structure. (D) View along the crystallographic c axis illustrating the packing of chains within the crystal mediated by interdigitation of the alanine methyl groups and hydrogen bonding between backbone amide groups (hydrogen bonds shown in blue).

elements.content: Similarly to the case of complex 1, two trialanine peptide linkers bridge between two Cd ions in an antiparallel orientation to form a ring. Most interestingly, the tripeptide is seen to fold around the methyl group of the N-terminal alanine residue so that it points into the center of the ring. Together with the side chain from the opposing tripeptide, the two methyl groups form a hydrophobic core that fills the central cavity of the ring (Figure B). This folding disposes the methyl groups of the second and third residues to face outward, where they make hydrophobic contacts with methyl groups of adjacent metal−peptide chains. These interchain hydrophobic contacts propagate the structure in the second dimension (Figure D).

Most interestingly, the tripeptide is seen to fold around the methyl group of the N-terminal alanine residue so that it points into the center of the ring. Together with the side chain from the opposing tripeptide, the two methyl groups form a hydrophobic core that fills the central cavity of the ring (Figure B). This folding disposes the methyl groups of the second and third residues to face outward, where they make hydrophobic contacts with methyl groups of adjacent metal-peptide chains. These interchain hydrophobic contacts propagate the structure in the second dimension (Figure D).

elements.content: Hydrogen bonding interactions between amide N−H and carbonyl oxygens propagate the structure in the third dimension. Two hydrogen bonds, between the first and second N−H and carbonyl groups, connect each peptide to its counterpart in the next layer of the structure. Steric hindrance from the side chains means that potential hydrogen bonding interactions with the third N−H group and the unligated carboxylate oxygen are not satisfied.

elements.content: Given the key role that the side chains play in the structure of Cd(Ala3)2, we next investigated the effect of reducing the linker length by crystallizing the Cd dialanine complex, Cd(Ala2)2. This complex crystallized as orthorhombic crystals belonging to the space group P21212. The complex adopts a completely different 2-D peptide−metal framework in which four dipeptide linkers form a highly distorted square lattice, as shown in Figure . Surprisingly, the peptide adopts three different bridging modes between Cd ions, which results in two chemically distinct modes of cadmium ligation (Figure D, E). In one bridging mode (the “long” mode), the N-terminus amino group acts as a monodentate ligand and the C-terminal carboxylate is also a monodentate ligand. In another bridging mode (the “short” mode), the N-terminus acts as a bidentate ligand with both the NH2- and amide carbonyl groups coordinating the metal, whereas the C-terminal carboxylate group is now a bidentate ligand. The third bridging mode (the “medium” mode) involves the N-terminus acting as a bidentate ligand through the NH2- and amide carbonyl groups, but the C-terminal carboxylate group is monodentate. In the structure, one set of Cd ions is ligated by the N-termini of two “short” linkers and the C-termini of two “long” linkers, whereas the other set is ligated by the N-terminus of a “long” linker, the C-terminus of a “short” linker, the N-terminus of a “medium” linker, and the C-terminus of a second “medium” linker. Both sets of Cd ions are pseudo-octahedrally coordinated, with the two nitrogen ligands occupying adjacent positions.

This complex crystallized as orthorhombic crystals belonging to the space group P21212. The complex adopts a completely different 2-D peptide-metal framework in which four dipeptide linkers form a highly distorted square lattice, as shown in Figure . Surprisingly, the peptide adopts three different bridging modes between Cd ions, which results in two chemically distinct modes of cadmium ligation (Figure D, E). In one bridging mode (the "long" mode), the N-terminus amino group acts as a monodentate ligand and the C-terminal carboxylate is also a monodentate ligand. In another bridging mode (the "short" mode), the N-terminus acts as a bidentate ligand with both the NH2- and amide carbonyl groups coordinating the metal, whereas the C-terminal carboxylate group is now a bidentate ligand. The third bridging mode (the "medium" mode) involves the N-terminus acting as a bidentate ligand through the NH2- and amide carbonyl groups, but the C-terminal carboxylate group is monodentate. In the structure, one set of Cd ions is ligated by the N-termini of two "short" linkers and the C-termini of two "long" linkers, whereas the other set is ligated by the N-terminus of a "long" linker, the C-terminus of a "short" linker, the N-terminus of a "medium" linker, and the C-terminus of a second "medium" linker. Both sets of Cd ions are pseudo-octahedrally coordinated, with the two nitrogen ligands occupying adjacent positions.

elements.content: The resulting combinations of “long”, “medium”, and “short” dialanine linkers give rise to two types of lattice spaces in the crystal. The interior space of each lattice element is filled by four methyl side chains, one from each of the dipeptides that define the lattice. The alanine methyl groups pack together to produce a hydrophobic core that most likely stabilizes the structure and explains the preference for a 2-D “square” network over the 1-D linear chain formed by the Cd (Ala3)2 complex.

The interior space of each lattice element is filled by four methyl side chains, one from each of the dipeptides that define the lattice. The alanine methyl groups pack together to produce a hydrophobic core that most likely stabilizes the structure and explains the preference for a 2-D "square" network over the 1-D linear chain formed by the Cd (Ala3)2 complex.

elements.content: As with the other peptide−metal frameworks, hydrogen bonding between the layers of the 2-D lattice allows the structure to propagate in the third dimension. Each peptide donates and accepts two hydrogen bonds to other peptides in adjacent layers. However, the hydrogen bonding pattern is complicated because the “long”, “short”, and “medium” peptide linkers each make slightly different hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: We were able to modify the 2-D dialanine framework, by substituting one alanine residue by threonine. The -CH(OH)CH3 side chain of threonine is amphiphilic, possessing both methyl and hydroxyl groups. The Cd complex of this peptide crystallized as monoclinic crystals belonging to the space group C2. The structure of Cd(Ala-Thr)2 exhibits the same 2-dimensional topology as that of Cd(Ala2)2, again forming a “square” lattice in which four peptides are linked together by four cadmium ions (Figure ). In this case, each dipeptide acts as a “medium” length linker, coordinating Cd ions in a bidentate manner through the N-terminus (NH2- and amide carbonyl ligation) and at the C-terminus through monodentate carboxylate ligation. This results in a more regular structure. Again, each lattice space is filled by four side chains (two Ala, two Thr), one from each peptide linker.

elements.content: Most strikingly, the hydroxyl group of threonine points out of the lattice and recruits a layer of water molecules between the adjacent sheets of the lattice, as shown in Figure D and E. Two water molecules per peptide (four per asymmetric unit) are incorporated into the structure, where they form an extensive hydrogen bonding network with the backbone oxygen and NH groups and the threonine hydroxyl. The result is that, unlike all the other structures, there are no direct hydrogen bonding interactions between adjacent layers of the 2-D network.

elements.content: To date, the vast majority of MOF-like structures have been synthesized using rigid organic ligands that incorporate hydrophobic aromatic rings or C−C double or triple bonds as spacers. These typically result in open 3-D networks characterized by a degree of porosity. The synthesis of metal−peptide framework compounds introduces ligands with very different properties from those of conventional MOFs. The peptide backbone is intrinsically flexible, and each amide linkage incorporates both a hydrogen bond donor (N−H) and an acceptor (C=O) into the ligand that will need to be satisfied to minimize the energy of any given structure. The nature of the side chain, its size, and whether it is hydrophobic or hydrophilic will also strongly influence the properties of the peptide. In the structures described above, all of these properties of peptides are seen to play important roles in defining the networks that are formed. In general, these properties of peptides will tend to mediate against the formation of classical open, 3-D MOF-like structures in favor of more densely packed structures that are better able to maximize amide hydrogen bonds and side chain hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

To date, the vast majority of MOF-like structures have been synthesized using rigid organic ligands that incorporate hydrophobic aromatic rings or C-C double or triple bonds as spacers. These typically result in open 3-D networks characterized by a degree of porosity. The synthesis of metal-peptide framework compounds introduces ligands with very different properties from those of conventional MOFs. The peptide backbone is intrinsically flexible, and each amide linkage incorporates both a hydrogen bond donor (N-H) and an acceptor (C=O) into the ligand that will need to be satisfied to minimize the energy of any given structure. The nature of the side chain, its size, and whether it is hydrophobic or hydrophilic will also strongly influence the properties of the peptide. In the structures described above, all of these properties of peptides are seen to play important roles in defining the networks that are formed. In general, these properties of peptides will tend to mediate against the formation of classical open, 3-D MOF-like structures in favor of more densely packed structures that are better able to maximize amide hydrogen bonds and side chain hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions.

elements.content: The cadmium complexes we have characterized share some general features that may allow some conclusions to be drawn regarding the assembly of metal−peptide frameworks. In each case, the complex is overall electroneutral and the cadmium is six-coordinate, with a [2N + 4O] ligand set. For the Ala2, Ala3, and Ala−Thr complexes, this results in four peptides coordinating each metal ion, two by their N-termini and two by their C-termini. It appears that the bridging carboxylate mode seen in the triglycine complex, 1, that results in six peptides coordinating each metal is atypical, probably because glycine lacks a side chain that would otherwise prevent the coordination of the additional peptide chains. Cadmium coordination appears to be a robust means of assembling peptides, in that the [2N + 4O] ligand set can be achieved in a variety of ways and distortions from octahedral geometry are tolerated, as illustrated by the Cd(Ala2)2 complex, 3.

For the Ala2, Ala3, and Ala-Thr complexes, this results in four peptides coordinating each metal ion, two by their N-termini and two by their C-termini. It appears that the bridging carboxylate mode seen in the triglycine complex, 1, that results in six peptides coordinating each metal is atypical, probably because glycine lacks a side chain that would otherwise prevent the coordination of the additional peptide chains. Cadmium coordination appears to be a robust means of assembling peptides, in that the [2N + 4O] ligand set can be achieved in a variety of ways and distortions from octahedral geometry are tolerated, as illustrated by the Cd(Ala2)2 complex, 3.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that crystals were not obtained with the other divalent metals we tried; with the exception of the triglycine complex, not even zinc was able to substitute for cadmium. It is not obvious why cadmium should be special in this regard, but our results suggest a requirement for a large divalent metal ion to accommodate the ligand set. In particular, the amino acid side chain imposes steric constraints that may restrict the ability of the four peptide chains necessary to propagate the structure to coordinate a smaller metal ion.

It is not obvious why cadmium should be special in this regard, but our results suggest a requirement for a large divalent metal ion to accommodate the ligand set. In particular, the amino acid side chain imposes steric constraints that may restrict the ability of the four peptide chains necessary to propagate the structure to coordinate a smaller metal ion.

elements.content: It appears that dipeptide linkers used in complexes 3 and 4 form 2-D covalent frameworks at least in part because steric crowding imposed by the amino acid side chains prevents two peptides bridging between the same two metals. However, as illustrated by the structure of Cd (Ala3)2 (2), if longer peptides are used, the backbone can now fold around the side chain to form 1-D chains that allow the peptide to pack efficiently together. In all cases, interpeptide hydrogen bonds play an important structural role in the crystal. The 1-D and 2-D frameworks exhibited by these compounds appear to maximize the number of hydrogen bonding interactions by forming layered materials. The extensive hydrogen bonding between layers is reminiscent of β-sheet structures commonly found in proteins.

The 1-D and 2-D frameworks exhibited by these compounds appear to maximize the number of hydrogen bonding interactions by forming layered materials. The extensive hydrogen bonding between layers is reminiscent of β-sheet structures commonly found in proteins.

elements.content: One question that arises from these studies is whether the structures can be modified in a predictable manner by changing the amino acid side chains. The Cd(Ala3)2 structure, 2, is particularly interesting in this regard, as the first alanine residue appears to nucleate the folding of the tripeptide, leaving residues 2 and 3 oriented to make interchain contacts. This would suggest that there might be scope for modulating the properties of this material by changing the side chains at these positions, while leaving the basic chain connectivity intact. A further challenge is the synthesis of 3-D metal−peptide frameworks. This might be achieved by incorporating amino acids such as glutamate or lysine that contain carboxylate and amine functional groups, respectively, that could coordinate metal ions and extend the structure in the third dimension.

A further challenge is the synthesis of 3-D metal-peptide frameworks. This might be achieved by incorporating amino acids such as glutamate or lysine that contain carboxylate and amine functional groups, respectively, that could coordinate metal ions and extend the structure in the third dimension.

elements.content: Lastly, we note that there is considerable interest in the second order nonlinear optical properties of ordered chiral materials for various electro-optical applications. Compounds 2–4 all form chiral crystals by virtue of the homochiral peptide linkers. Although these complexes lack suitable chromophores for optical applications, one could envision that, by either substituting a suitable transition metal or introducing a chromophoric side chain, novel optical materials could be developed.

All complexes were crystallized by the base diffusion method. The crystallization trials were conducted at room temperature, which varied between 20 and 25 °C.

Synthesis of Cd(Gly<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of CdAc2 (14 mg, 0.05 mmol) and Gly3 tripeptide (10 mg, 0.05 mmol) in 2.0 mL of DMF, water, and ethanol (1:1:1.5) was prepared. The solution was sonicated for 5 min with gentle shaking at 150 w using a Fisher Scientific FS60 ultrasonic bath and placed in a 5 mL glass vial, which was in turn was placed in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. One milliliter of 2% triethylamine in ethanol solution was added to the 20 mL vial and sealed with a cap. After about 3 months, colorless needles had grown; these were separated, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (59% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm−1): 3453, 3293, 3100, 2938, 2816, 1675, 1649, 1577, 1423, 1381, 1290, 1258, 1061, 1027, 1015, 715, 596, 477.

Synthesis of Cd(<sc>l</sc>-Ala<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution of CdAc2 (40 mg, 0.15 mmol) and l-Ala3 tripeptide (50 mg, 0.15 mmol) in 10 mL of DMF, water, and ethanol solution (2:2:1) was prepared. The solution was sonicated, as described for 1, and placed in a 20 mL vial, which was in turn placed in a 100 mL screw-capped jar. Ten milliliters of 2% triethylamine solution was added to the 100 mL jar and sealed with a cap. After about 3 weeks, colorless transparent needles had grown; these were washed with ethanol and air-dried (43% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm−1): 3376, 3258, 3223, 3067, 2986, 2937, 1679, 1639, 1592, 1516, 1444, 1413, 1142, 1110, 1029, 694.

Synthesis of Cd(<sc>l</sc>-Ala<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A solution of CdAc2 (16 mg, 0.06 mmol) and l-Ala2 dipeptide (10 mg, 0.12 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF, water, and ethanol solution (1:1:1.5) was prepared. The solution was sonicated, as described for 1, and placed in a 5 mL glass vial, which was in turn was placed in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. Two milliliters of 2% triethylamine solution was added to the 20 mL vial and sealed with a cap. After about 4 weeks, colorless transparent needles had grown; these were separated, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (62% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm−1): 3346, 3322, 3287, 3242, 3131, 3078, 2969, 2933, 1644, 1563, 1513, 1442, 1401, 1147, 1101, 1001, 857, 686.

A solution of CdAc2 (16 mg, 0.06 mmol) and l-Ala-l-Thr dipeptide (10 mg, 0.12 mmol) in 2 mL of water was prepared. The solution was sonicated, as described for 1, and placed in a 5 mL glass vial, which was in turn was placed in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. Two milliliters of 2% triethylamine solution was added to the 20 mL vial and sealed with a cap. After about 3 weeks, colorless transparent needles had grown; these were washed with ethanol and air-dried (60% yield, based on cadmium). Synthesis of Cd(l-Ala3)2 (2)

A solution of CdAc2 (40 mg, 0.15 mmol) and l-Ala3 tripeptide (50 mg, 0.15 mmol) in 10 mL of DMF, water, and ethanol solution (2:2:1) was prepared. The solution was sonicated, as described for 1, and placed in a 20 mL vial, which was in turn placed in a 100 mL screw-capped jar. Ten milliliters of 2% triethylamine solution was added to the 100 mL jar and sealed with a cap. After about 3 weeks, colorless transparent needles had grown; these were washed with ethanol and air-dried (43% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm-1): 3376, 3258, 3223, 3067, 2986, 2937, 1679, 1639, 1592, 1516, 1444, 1413, 1142, 1110, 1029, 694.

Synthesis of Cd(l-Ala2)2 (3)

A solution of CdAc2 (16 mg, 0.06 mmol) and l-Ala2 dipeptide (10 mg, 0.12 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF, water, and ethanol solution (1:1:1.5) was prepared. The solution was sonicated, as described for 1, and placed in a 5 mL glass vial, which was in turn was placed in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. Two milliliters of 2% triethylamine solution was added to the 20 mL vial and sealed with a cap. After about 4 weeks, colorless transparent needles had grown; these were separated, washed with ethanol, and air-dried (62% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm-1): 3346, 3322, 3287, 3242, 3131, 3078, 2969, 2933, 1644, 1563, 1513, 1442, 1401, 1147, 1101, 1001, 857, 686.

Crystallization of Cd(l-Ala-l-Thr)2⋅4H2O (4)

A solution of CdAc2 (16 mg, 0.06 mmol) and l-Ala-l-Thr dipeptide (10 mg, 0.12 mmol) in 2 mL of water was prepared. The solution was sonicated, as described for 1, and placed in a 5 mL glass vial, which was in turn was placed in a 20 mL screw-capped vial. Two milliliters of 2% triethylamine solution was added to the 20 mL vial and sealed with a cap. After about 3 weeks, colorless transparent needles had grown; these were washed with ethanol and air-dried (60% yield, based on cadmium). FTIR data (cm-1): 3447, 3372, 3316, 3271, 3170, 2968, 2921, 1668, 1645, 1604, 1584, 1533, 1418, 1395, 1242, 1123, 1083, 1060, 1040, 801.

cln_elements.content: Network formed by the prototypical metal−peptide framework complex Cd(Gly2)2·H2O: (A) When viewed along the crystallographic b axis, the extended network formed by the bridging diglycine linkers is clearly illustrated. Note: In this view, the Cd ions are eclipsed so that it appears that the carboxylate groups form bidentate ligands to cadmium, but this is not the case. As shown in part B, when viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the 8-membered rings formed by Cd-bridging carboxylate groups are clearly displayed.
